metadata.sermon_start_end: A few years ago I had a good-natured dispute with a friend of mine. He was an admirer of a certain well-known celebrity preacher. I said I thought this preacher was shallow. My friend, a businessman, said, as though to clinch the argument, “He’s not shallow! He preaches good common sense!” [...] Against all common sense, the power of God has intervened on our side through the sacrifice of the only Son for our sin. Who is Jesus? “For our sake [God] made him to be sin who knew no sin, so that in him we might become the righteousness of God.” AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon centers on the Pauline antithesis between human wisdom and the cross. However, it treats the text more as a 'biblical idea' (the folly of the cross) than as a unique pericope. It fails Dekker's test of finding what is in THIS text that is nowhere else, as it leans heavily on 2 Corinthians 5 and Isaiah 53 to explain the passage.
quotes: Last week’s reading and this one lie at the nerve center of Paul’s teaching
The approach of Lent means that you and I... are going to be turning our attention to what Paul calls 'the word of the cross'.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Isolate the specific rhetorical situation of Corinth in chapter 2: why did Paul specifically choose 'weakness, fear, and trembling' there, rather than a general discourse on the cross?

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is thin. There is no mention of the Greek context of 'sophia' or 'logos' beyond generalities. The preacher does not engage with the historical-critical reality of the Corinthian church's specific conflicts, treating them as a generic stand-in for modern 'easy answers'.
quotes: Paul writes to explain that they have it all wrong
It is hard for us to understand what an affront to common sense it was to preach a crucified Messiah.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific cultural weight of 'lofty words of wisdom' in the Greco-Roman rhetorical tradition to show why Paul’s refusal was a professional scandal.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest element. Using the Pope’s appeal for Darrell Mease and the critique of John Gray’s self-help book provides the 'concrete truth' Dekker demands. It avoids generalities by naming specific cultural idols (common sense, self-improvement).
quotes: I feel, God forgive me for saying this, that it may be common sense to have the death penalty.
John Gray offers the ultimate guide to personal success... joy, confidence and contentment in just four easy-to-follow steps.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the 'weakness and fear' of the preacher (v. 3) more concretely to the modern preacher’s own lack of 'common sense' solutions.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon moves back and forth between the Corinthian text and contemporary examples (Mease, Gray). However, the text often serves as a 'hook' for the examples rather than the hearer being 'expounded' by the text itself.
quotes: I thought about that last month when I read the coverage about Pope John Paul’s visit
Compare these four steps... with the twelve steps of AA.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid using the text as a springboard for anecdotes; let the contemporary situation be judged by the specific grammar of the verse.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes misery (sin, death penalty, perpetrators) and redemption (substitutionary atonement). It correctly identifies man as the subject of this misery before God. Gratitude is less explicit but implied in the 'transformed life'.
quotes: You and I were condemned to death because of sin.
Jesus takes all that into himself... the One who hangs there is the Son of God, who suffered the death penalty instead of us.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Develop the 'gratitude' aspect more specifically—what does a life 'transformed' by the folly of the cross look like in practice?

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are present in the contrast between 'those who are perishing' and 'those who are being saved'. The sermon acknowledges the seriousness of being 'condemned to death', but the 'lostness' feels more like a theological category than an urgent choice for the hearer.
quotes: For the word of the cross is folly to those who are perishing, but to us who are being saved it is the power of God.
Our situation could not be more serious.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'willing and responsible being' more directly. What is the consequence of choosing 'common sense' over the Cross today?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: The sermon is rigorously Christocentric. Christ is the telos and the only source of salvation. The preacher correctly identifies that Christ must be God for the cross to be the 'power of God'.
quotes: I decided to know nothing among you except Jesus Christ and him crucified.
God has suffered cruel and inhuman punishment... the One who hangs there is the Son of God.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure the 'two natures' doctrine is not just assumed but shown as the reason why the Cross is 'power' rather than just 'tragedy'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1,550 words, the sermon likely clocks in at 15-16 minutes. According to Dekker's Thesis 8, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to reach the 20-minute threshold and provide the necessary theological 'breadth'.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short primarily on duration and exegetical depth, failing to meet the 20-minute requirement and lacking engagement with original languages or specific historical context. However, it succeeds in its sharp rejection of 'common sense' and its concrete, contemporary application regarding the death penalty and self-help culture.
strengths: Concrete application: The use of the Darrell Mease case provides a sharp, non-general illustration of the 'scandal' of grace.
Theological focus: Maintains a strict Christocentric focus on substitutionary atonement without softening the 'misery' of sin.
weaknesses: Insufficient length: The sermon is too short to allow the 'breadth' Miskotte and Dekker demand.
Weak exegesis: The preacher relies on systematic theological categories rather than the specific linguistic and historical particularity of the Corinthian passage.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'strong speech' that approaches being a sermon, but lacks the exegetical rigor and temporal breadth required by Dekker's theses. It identifies the 'folly' of the gospel well but treats the Bible passage as a theme rather than a unique, current word.
